transcripts.text: I want to play something real quick because this is important.  It's a very important point you're going into.  Hold that thought.  Dorsey, can we play the clip on CNN with Jamal Bowman?
So based on Biden's elections so far, do you see anyone that's progressive enough for you?

Well, first, let me say off the top, thank you so much for having me.  When I hear names like Rahm Emanuel being floated as part of Biden's cabinet, considering the fact that he covered up the murder of Laquan McDonald in Chicago, considering the fact that he closed over 50 elementary schools and 30 mental health institutions, it's incredibly alarming.
That's the story of me on CNN, too.
They were, like, sitting there with me, and they're like, and here's your new contributor.
Oh, did you just say you're not endorsing Hillary today, but in a month?  Oh, bye-bye.  Or you on MSNBC, we know the story.

Me on MSNBC.  Yeah, I mean, we've talked about this.  I mean, a very telling thing just happened.  Ariana Picari, who is a producer for Lawrence O'Donnell, who I've been talking with for a while, because she knows of my history.  And I can say this in public now because she just came out on this Andrew Yang program and said, look, MSNBC, MSNBC, MSNBC has been telling people you can't book these people, right?  And I have been told explicitly in no uncertain terms by high level MSNBC people that there's no such thing as a no-fly list.  It doesn't exist.
Meaning a blacklist at MSNBC.  Meaning a blacklist that you can't put people on.

And I've been told explicitly by high-level people at MSNBC that, of course, there was a no-fly list, right?  So we have confirmation from somebody who's actually just taken an extraordinary brave stance and said, by the way, it's all controlled.  This is not about who's best at talking on television.  It's not about who's most informed at talking on television.  It's never about ratings.  Yeah.  It's about who will actually say what, yeah, there we go.  Thanks, Dorsey.  That's my question.  What's truth, right?  And I'm looking forward to having Ariana on my show soon.  But honestly, that was pretty blatant.  That was literally like the state-controlled media being like, yank, yoink.  It wasn't even like a physical, yeah.  Let me say this.  Go back to your original point, though.  In terms of the infiltrators, right?  Yeah.  We're seeing infiltration at a lot of different levels.  Bezos' money is infiltration.  That's just bottom line.  Bloomberg's money is infiltration in the Sierra Club, right?  You know, Eric Schmidt's money is infiltration.
And what comes with that money is staff, too, by the way.  Let's be very clear.

Here's the thing.  When you staff up an environmental organization, your priority becomes feeding the monkey.  You've got to feed that staff.  You've got to get that money again.  You've got to get it back.  So you're going to talk to the people who are doing that stuff, like who are giving you the money.  You're going to find out what they like, right?  Instead of staffing up, what they need to be doing is paying grassroots organizers in the streets.  The only good thing that these environmental organizations could do possibly would be to regrant this money, to regrant it, to identify.  And they know who they are.  They know who they are.  They know who they are because they're the same members, right?  All the mom and pop environmental organizations are members of Sierra Club.  Well, Sierra Club didn't get the money, which is interesting because Sierra Club actually does do some of this, but they took Bloomberg's money.  Right.  So the best thing that these environmental organizations could do, instead of hiring 50 more lawyers from Harvard, which is always what they do.

They should go into the, they got to go to the small towns in the United States that are fighting an LNG terminal, that are fighting a coal mine, that are fighting a compressor station, that are fighting a fracking field and say, you know what?  This is your money.  You go and do what you need to do with it.  And some people will definitely take that and make that a job, you know?  But listen, but that's not going to be in a big office building in San Francisco where... I don't even want to get into it because the bottom line is the San Francisco Environmental Mafia, as I call them, did more damage to the New York environmental movement.  that was real honest and real going out and gutsy, you know, just as a matter of tone.  We were there to fight.  You know, we're from New York.  We're like getting ready to bruise.  And then all of a sudden it's like, oh, wait a minute.  Stop raising your voice.
